<3 you guys. Very cool, Eric et al. So, pretty much simultaneously with you launching this we yesterday launched a new set of handy pop-up endpoints for fave/reply/rt and so on and so forth for situations exactly like this, so you can quote Tweets anywhere on the web, and but keep them linked back to Twitter interactions with just a few little links. We've called them Web Intents, and I will personally buy you a beer if you add them to your beautiful new quotes. http://t.co/paMSjlX

(I should probably disclaim at this point that the offer of ‘Free Beer for implementing Web Intents’ is not official Twitter policy, and is rather more to do with the fact I haven't been for a drink with Eric in months.)

@llimllib I wouldn't call this an embed, it's a copy. An embedded Tweet would live on a Twitter server, just as the video underlying a Youtube embed will live on Youtube. The difference is, if the tweet is deleted, or the user changes real name or private/public status, these changes are not reflected in the copy shown on Convore.

Actually I am not aware of any Twitter TOS that cover display/takedown of a stored tweet that has been deleted, or status changed to private. @BenWard?

@BenWard, thanks for that. I agree that a public Tweet is a quotable resource, especially as it is likely to be quoted in its entirety. Our site digs up older Tweets to use as conversation starters and it wouldn't shock me to oneday get a request for removal, which I would honor.

Regarding intents, I am very tempted - I feel we would lose fewer interactions than we would by forcing the user through OAuth for a simple retweet. I don't care that much about gaining new registered users of our app - I care more about the content - but OAuth allows us to know that one of our stored Tweets has been faved/replied/retweeted so we can add this information. What might work would be a callback attached to the intent that would return some data on the action performed.
